share.share_text:
Mill Valley Film Festival, 1985.

Since founding the Mill Valley Film Festival in 1977, Mark Fishkin has shepherded this once small, three-day showcase into an eleven-day, internationally acclaimed cinema event presenting a wide variety of new films from around the world.

The festival has a track record of launching new films and new filmmakers, and has earned a reputation as a filmmakersâ festival by celebrating the best in American independent and foreign films.

Each year the festival welcomes more than 200 filmmakers, representing more than 50 countries. Screening sections include World Cinema; US Cinema; Docs; Family Films; Shorts; and Active Cinema, MVFFâs activist films initiative.

ð¥: Mill Valley Film Festival

Screen legend Buster Keaton sitting at a bar in Culver City in 1955, looking like a hardened detective from the greatest film noir never made. 

In actuality, this bar was built on a soundstage at Hal Roach Studios for the filming of an episode of NBCâs Screen Directorâs Playhouse titled âThe Silent Partner,â in which Keaton plays a forgotten silent film star made to reflect on his career when a former co-star (played by Joe E. Brown) wins an Academy Award and thanks him in his speech. As Keatonâs character watches this from a crowded bar, heâs further confronted with his past when the television then plays the fictional film that they once made together.

â¦and this is the real point of the episode, as this framing device sets them up to debut a new silent two-reel comedy with Keaton, Brown, and ZaSu Pitts, more than 25 years after filmâs transition to sound. The episode was directed by George Marshall, whose own career started in the silent era, directing the westerns of Harry Carey, and later Tom Mix, and a number of Laurel & Hardy films as well.

This was made at a time when Keaton was experiencing something of a revival thanks to the rise of television, which created a renewed interest in silent cinema in the early 1950s. Then, through an incredible stroke of dumb luck, a trove of Keatonâs old film reels were discovered by English actor James Mason, who had purchased Keatonâs old house in 1952. Mason reportedly arranged to have the decomposing films transferred to Cellulose acetate film (âsafety filmâ) for preservation, and had them delivered the collection to Keaton, who then entered discussions with a film distributor to get them back into theaters.

The Screen Directorâs Playhouse was just one of more than 70 guest appearances that Keaton made on television over the course of the next decade, and he returned to the big screen more than a dozen times with cameo roles up through the end of his life. 

â

Photo by Loomis Dean for LIFE Magazine

share.share_text: In November we celebrate the career of filmmaker James Bridges, present world cinema classics by Kurosawa and AlmodÃ³var, host a Judy Garland Thanksgiving, pre-code Stanwyck & much more!
